H0.text: Macrophages are the cells that HIV targets, making the body vulnerable to secondary infections.

H1.text: Helper T‑cells are the target of HIV, making the body vulnerable to secondary infections.

H2.text: Cells are targeted by HIV, making the body vulnerable to secondary infections.

H3.text: Killer T‑cells are targeted by HIV, making the body vulnerable to secondary infections.

A4.text: HIV infects vital cells in the human immune system, such as helper T cells (specifically CD4+ T cells), macrophages, and dendritic cells.

A5.text: When CD4+ T cell numbers decline below a critical level, cell-mediated immunity is lost, and the body becomes progressively more susceptible to opportunistic infections, leading to the development of AIDS.
